did.unittitle: Jane Ellis Papers
did.abstract: The Jane Ellis Papers contain materials produced or collected by Jane Ellis, the Keston Institute’s principal scholar on the Russian Orthodox Church in the twentieth century and a leading expert on the religious situation in the Soviet Union and post-Soviet Russia.

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: Jane Elizabeth Ellis was born on August 3, 1951, in Liverpool. As a teenager, Ellis became a member of the evangelical branch of the Church of England. After attending an evangelistic rally led by Brother Andrew, she became interested in the life of Christian believers in the Soviet Union. She taught herself Russian and studied Russian Language and Literature at Birmingham University. Upon her graduation in 1973, Ellis founded Aid for Russian Christians (ARC), the first organization that systematically provided material aid and spiritual support to oppressed religious believers in the Soviet Union. She served as ARC Director until 1986.

In 1975, Jane Ellis joined the Keston College (later Keston Institute) staff as a full-time researcher and analyst gathering and interpreting information on religion in the Soviet Union. By her mid-30s, Ellis had established a reputation as the one of the world’s leading authorities on the Russian Orthodox Church in the twentieth century and an expert on the religious situation in the Soviet Union and post-Soviet Russia. Her most prominent publications included The Russian Orthodox Church: A Contemporary History (Croom Helm, 1986) and The Russian Orthodox Church: Triumphalism and Defensiveness (Macmillan, 1996) as well as translations of books previously published as samizdat. Ellis translated into English an original samizdat text about the life of Orthodox elder Fr. Zacharia. Written by one of his spiritual daughters and smuggled out of the Soviet Union, Keston published the translation in 1976 as An Early Soviet Saint: The Life of Father Zachariah. Ellis also translated and wrote an introduction for the samizdat autobiography of persecuted Unregistered Baptist Georgi Vins which was published in the United Kingdom as Three Generations of Suffering (Hodder and Stoughton, 1976) and in the United States as Georgi Vins: Prisoner of Conscience (David C. Cook, 1979). Her book on the history of the Russian Orthodox Church was translated into several other languages, including Russian.
Jane Ellis served as editor of the Keston Institute’s academic journal Religion in Communist Lands from 1981 to 1986 and the Institute’s magazine Frontier from 1987 to 1990.

During perestroika and until her death in 1998, Jane Ellis spent most of her time in Moscow where she established a Keston office. A deeply committed ecumenist, she played a key role in promoting a discussion between Christians of different denominations in the Soviet Union and post-Soviet Russia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The Jane Ellis papers cover the period from 1949 to 1998 with the bulk from 1974 to 1995. The materials focus on the history of the Russian Orthodox Church, the Church’s relations with other denominations, the lives of individual Orthodox clergy and believers, church-state relations, state policy on religion, and religious persecution in the Soviet Union and post-Soviet Russia.

Literary Works and Subject files are the largest series in the collection. Literary Works contains materials Ellis wrote and collected while working on books and articles, planning lectures and interviews, preparing conference papers, translating, and editing. The series pertains primarily to Ellis’ published works. The series also includes items related to unfinished and unpublished writing projects. Subject Files contains materials collected for research projects, including political and religious organizations, sects, religious freedom, Orthodox bishops and clergy, and Orthodox-Protestant dialog in the former Soviet Union.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Keston Center received Jane Ellis Papers in folders with titles. Materials were organized into series according to their nature and topic and arranged chronologically.
The Jane Ellis Papers are organized into four series: I. Correspondence, II. Literary Works, III. Subject Files, and IV. Personal.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: All requests for copying of materials must be submitted to the Keston Center for Religion, Politics, and Society in writing. Please use the Request Form for Copying Materials sheet. Unpublished materials authored or otherwise produced by the creator (s) of this collection are in the public domain. There are no restrictions on use. Copyright status for other collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Jane Ellis Papers, Box #, Folder #, Keston Center for Religion, Politics, and Society, Baylor University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Described by Larisa Seago. Released on 2021-12-15.

did.unittitle: Correspondence

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: The series contains correspondence sent and received by Jane Ellis during her term at the Keston Institute. The most notable topics include an honorary doctoral degree for murdered Russian priest Fr. Alexader Men’, the True Orthodox (Catacomb) Church, and Soviet dissident Alexander Ogorodnikov.
The series is in good condition.

Literary Works

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: The largest series of the collection, Literary Works, includes correspondence, handwritten notes, draft manuscripts, research materials, and book reviews produced and collected by Jane Ellis while working on her books, translations, articles, and reports.

The materials pertain mainly to Ellis’ published works, including, Three Generations of Suffering and An Early Soviet Saint: the Life of Father Zachariah (1976), The Russian Orthodox Church: A Contemporary History (1986), and The Russian Orthodox Church: Triumphalism and Defensiveness (1996), book chapters, and articles. Some materials pertain to unpublished or unfinished writing projects, including One Man's Witness: Select Writings of Anatolii Levitin-Krasnov and the English translation of Lev Regelson’s The Tragedy of the Russian Church.
The series is in good condition.

Subject Files

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: The second largest series, Subject Files, includes newspaper clippings, manuscripts, photographs, print materials, and correspondence pertaining to Jane Ellis’ research interests. The most notable topics include but are not limited to Aleksandr Ogorodnikov’s Christian Democratic Union, Russian Orthodox Church, True Orthodox (Catacomb) Church, Ukrainian Orthodox Church, Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church, Orthodox Bishops, Russian Orthodox Church and Vatican relations, the 1989 meeting between Mikhail Gorbachev and Pope John Paul II, and Orthodox-Protestant dialog. Prominent individuals include Patriarch Alexii II (Ridiger), Fr. Aleksandr Men’, Fr. Georgii Kochetkov, and Konstantin Kharchev, the Chairman of the Council for Religious Affairs.
The series is in good condition.

Personal

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: The smallest series, Personal, contains Jane Ellis’ graduate school application and copies of her obituaries.

p.emph: The series is in good condition.
